title: Help me out here. Which characters are bruisers?
body:
Because bruisers are doing poorly from the air given off by the boards, but I can't get a concise list for which characters fit under this category. 

The term covers a wide swash of "semi-tanky fighters" which isn't very helpful, since it could range from juggernauts, to divers, to some wardens or vanguards or even skirmishers.

I get what people mean when they say "bruiser yi" or "bruiser Eve" were problems, because I get they mean those characters building half tanky and still doing ridiculous damage.

What I don't get is just the term "bruiser" as a class. Because the way I'm looking at it, as just tanky fighters, it would seem the opposite to the board's view. Top lane is being demolished by a mix of annoying poke champions and tanky juggernauts, and divers are taking the top spots in the jungle --

{{champion:75}} {{champion:420}} {{champion:164}} {{champion:240}} {{champion:266}} {{champion:122}} {{champion:86}} {{champion:107}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:114}} {{champion:83}}  make up 11 of the most winning toplaners with decent playrates (above 1%), while the jungle has a similar story for other fighters.

{{champion:19}} {{champion:72}} {{champion:164}} {{champion:5}} {{champion:102}} {{champion:107}} {{champion:24}} {{champion:77}} {{champion:80}} 

Pantheon is also doing well top, but falls more under the annoying poke category in that role, and other toplaners like Mordekaiser and Rumble, while doing well depending on the day, aren't putting consistent numbers.


So what exactly do people mean when they say that "bruisers" aren't doing well? Because all of these are fighters that build a mix of offense and defense, or build a lot of  one while their kit provides the other, all serving as well-performing tanky fighters.

There is a reason riot tried to push for [actual champion classes and subclass names](https://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/gameplay/taking-another-look-subclasses) instead of vague terms like 'bruiser'.

Sometimes people all think they're talking about the same thing when referring to 'bruisers', but might be thinking of different champs and then theres debates that end up "no, X isn't a bruiser, they're just a tank who happens to build a damage item" or similar not so productive things, so trying to get people on a common ground with terminology is a worthwhile endeavor.
To add to this, champions who have been considered to be bruisers, both in the past and present, are in the Juggernaut, Skirmisher, and Diver subclasses.

Skirmishers toe the line. Their builds are what defines them since alot of them have kits built around negating damage completely or having absurd dueling capabilities so tankiness isn't a necessity but still a viable option.

See: Bruiser Ekko vs AP Ekko, Bruiser Yi vs AD Yi, Bruiser Yasuo vs Crit Yasuo, etc.
Came here to comment this same thing. That being said the most common "bruisers" are Juggernauts and Divers.

now what I don't understand is why Shyvana is not considered a diver but instead a juggernaut who has been considered without any movement speed or gap-closing ability. Meanwhile Olaf is considered a diver instead of a juggernaut (I can agree with this). Note that Olaf was previously considered a juggernaut in a previous attempt to classify champions about 2 years ago.

and then Dr. Mundo is classified as fighter, instead of tank, when his entire kit is based around HP (has HP regen boost & MR boost), and literally everyone builds tanky on him right away instead of 1 item with AD/AP then into tanky items like traditional juggernauts.

also, why is cho'gath classified as unique playstyle when he seems to me like a warden tank (this I'm not sure, so I'm not going to disagree that quickly)

also, why is quinn unique playstyle when she's more of a hybrid marksman/assassin? 

if anything, jayce seems more like a unique playstyle. I know his Q is very potent and all but a huge number of circumstances involve throwing himself into the midst of battle unlike velkoz, xerath, and ziggs, who almost never shove their faces into the enemy team. 

and then there's Jhin who's listed as hybrid Catcher but not Ashe?

and I don't know if I would even mildly agree with their decision to lump Ashe through Xayah into one class without subclasses because Jhin clearly plays differently than Kog'Maw or Vayne

The key point to remember is that there is no point to this classification in itself. It's just a tool to analyze and compare different champs and to group relevant champs with similar kits together. A champ being officially sub-class X just means that's how Riot see them, but it's only a starting point, not a final word.

That being said, I was rather disappointed with the last version of the classification, and I disagreed with most of the changes compared to the previous one. So when we disagree on what the starting point even is, that doesn't help discussion... Below, a few case by case comments.

_____________

For Olaf and Shyvana, the back and forth between the different versions of the classification suggests to me that the current version just needs another sub-class. Other people that would go with Olaf and Shyv in that new sub-class would be Warwick, Volibear, Trundle, Udyr, etc. I've made a suggestion about that (and some other thing) here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1fSghVIlb1XdodKU0ze_gY4a57qwFFZWtuVX_d3Daryg/

Mundo is very definitely a Juggernaut, this one decision is perfectly sane and sound. He only has soft, single target CC, no way to peel for an ally, and no way to lock-down an enemy team with a big engage. In other words, he lacks all the key strengths of a proper Tank. His contribution to a team is mostly his own damage and not dying. That's what a Juggernaut provides, not a Tank.
(Note that if the additional sub-class I mentioned above was created, he might go there, but in the current system, there is no hesitation, he's clearly more Fighter than Tank, and he is no Diver, so he must be a Juggernaut.)

For the various Marksfolks, I'm more hesitant because I don't know those champs as well but what you've got to keep in mind is that: What do they provide to the team? Not what they look like.
Sure, Quinn "looks like" an ADC. But what will a good Quinn do in a game to get her Victory? Probably NOT stay in the middle of her team, close to her Support and Tank, contrary to "real" ADCs. She won't stay on the flanks either, waiting for an opportunity to jump into the enemy backline, because despite her super high MS, she has no good, free-range mobility like a true Assassin such as Zed, Kata, etc. Instead, she will try to roam, disorganize the enemy team, and hopefully win without ever needing to team-fight. So in the end: it's true that she has elements of both Marksfolk and Assassin, but what she actually does with those elements is neither what an ADC nor what an Assassin do. Her output is clearly different, and she has a truly unique playstyle.
Neither Ashe nor Jhin suprise me being or not being a Catcher, but I couldn't say which one the two most "deserve" it. Maybe Jhin, I agree, but I wouldn't be categorical. But more broadly, Riot tried to differentiate Marksfolks using "hybrid" notations, and I don't think that was a good idea, when all Marksfolks are still mostly here for their damage. Basically, Marksfolks are all here to provide damage+a little something, and the little something helps differentiate them **between all Marksfolks**, but it is not the main reason you pick them **over, say a Mage or a Controller**.
And I don't think most ADC play *that* differently from each others. Not to the point that they need different sub-classes. Ashe and Vayne play differently, but compare them to Ziggs versus Vladimir, and they suddenly look pretty similar.

Jayce, on the other hand, would be a good use of the hybrid notation, IMHO. What's the ouput he provides? Poke at the start of a fight, then he swap form and act as a Diver with weak CC. But he really plays like an Artillery at some points, and like a Diver at some others, not a uniquely different playstyle like Quinn. Jayce as a pure Artillery, though, I'm not convinced.

Cho'gath is an odd beast. I'd qualify him as an unreliable Tank with heavy damage to compensate, except that an unreliable Tank is no good Tank, and a Tank isn't interested in compensatory damage, it's not their job to deal damage. Maybe that's enough to make Cho a unique playstyle, maybe that just means he's outdated, I don't really know. But when you say he's a Warden, compare what he can do to what Poppy or Braum can do, and you'll see that he's not a *good* Warden.

A lot of those classifications are just flat out wrong. Amumu, alistar, braum, and chogath are all tanks. Alkali and Evelyn are assassins, and blitzcrank is too niche to be really be considered a bruiser.

Bruisers are typically the anti-tanks you see going top, and ironically losing lane to tanks.

Off the top of my head: Aatrox, Kled, Camille, Irelia, Kayn's Rhaast form, the list goes on.

A misconception is that characters like Riven, Yasuo, and Fiora are bruisers, they are actually Skirmishers. A Skirmisher is a highly mobile damage dealer with 1 powerful defensive steroid. (Fiora Riposte, Yasuo Windwall)
What's funny is that their mobility alone is a considerable defensive steroid, but i guess that gets written off and why they always feel painfully overtuned in lane.

Because mobility itself isn't strictly defensive or offensive. It can be tilted either way based on how the ability itself works, but mobility itself is neither offensive nor defensive.

Generally, for those three, their mobility is more offensive, rather than defensive. Yasuo dashes through enemies, Fiora's Q gets a partial reset on a dash to an enemy, Riven's mobility is tied to her offensive abilities.

It's less a defensive tool, and more a way back out.

But the point is that basically all dashes carry some amount of defensive capabilities, which means that if riot is only balancing the champions around their defensive steroid being the extent of their defense, the actual power of the champions is greater than intended by riot.

Bruisers build off-tank and look to grab items that give both damage and some defensive ability or stats. A lot of them look to carry in the midgame due to higher, non-scaling, flat damage that some of those items provide before being outscaled by the range and DPS (via crit/AD/AS) of ranged AD carries.

Prototypical bruisers build items like this: Triforce - Cleaver - Titanic - Sterak's - Death's Dance - BotRK (in the past) - Maw - Frozen Mallet (in the past) - Gunblade (rarely) - Iceborn (rarely) - Warmog's - Wit's End (sadly, extremely rarely).

IMO, the most absolute, archtypical, "cannot go wrong if you call them a bruiser" champions look something like Kled, Olaf, Jax, Renekton, Irelia, and Xin. Ideally, when these champions are fighting in the midgame, their opponents aren't exploding or anything, but these champs at this point in the game should be winning DPS races due to their spells, CC, and items spec'd for damage and enough survivability to utilize that damage.

They're not gonna win teamfights in a 5v5 because they tend to excel at picking on a single target and "duelling" them down, if given the opportunity, hence when they tend to be decent splitpushers.

I'm not going to comment on game balance or the state of the class of champion or anything like that. This archetype is supposed to have a clearly designed window of power in which to force the hand of the opponent by being separate from their team (should the situation need it) putting pressure on static objectives like towers and, in turn, eliciting a response from the enemy team, lest they lose a tower or even an inhibitor.

"Bruisers as they were called" means nothing. The term Bruiser was NEVER properly defined. The **point** of the new classification that introduced the term "Diver" was to create those precise definitions for the first time, and it actively avoided the previous terms to start on a clean slate.

And it failed, because people are still using the old vague terms instead of the new precisely defined terms.

Juggernauts and divers are clearly bruiser, skirmishers are in a gray area, if the built more tanky, they certainly can be seen as bruisers, if they go full glasscannon it wouldn#t really be a fitting term(hence why tanky builts for champs like Yi are reffered to as 'bruiser builts')

But most of the time when people reffer to bruisers, they retem to what Riot categoriced as ' Fighters'. with Juggernauts and Divers as subclasses.

I context of the 'bruisers are not doing well', there are some things to keep in mind.
One of the biggest things is ELO. Bruisers historically shine in lower elos and struggle in high elos, they are usually quite straight forward to play, strong at punishing mistakes, but easy to outplay as a team if you know what you're doing.
Especially in high dimond and beyond, many champs that can destroy low elos become non viable, while many champs with generally bad performance become busted. Ryze for example totally wrecks the game up there, but sucks pretty hard in lower elos.
Also, player experience and playrate are immmportant when talking about winrates. Many of the current high winrate tops have a low playrate(barely above 1%) and are mostly played by diehard mains(morde for example)
At the same time, many of the 'FotM' toplaners get played by not that experienced players and thus have lower winrates than you#d expect. 
Exeprience is a very important factor in top, many matchups are rather close and can snowball heavily, and more often than not it's about knwledge(experience) rather than raw mechanics so the difference between a OTP and FotM player is pretty massive.


Another thing is precived power and champion fantasy.
Shyvana for example performs pretty well right now, but all her power comes from her absurdly hgih clearspead and good dueling, so she just gets a huge XP and gold lead over the other jungler. On equal gold/XP in mid to lategame, she doesn't look any strong at all, and her teamfigthing later on, which is supposed one of her stregths and once upon the time also was, is pretty pathetic in higher elos.
Also, if played toplane, she just struggle alot. So yea, she performs well, but all that power comes from fas clears and if you can't snowball on the back of that, she does feel pretty weak, while the fantasy of the dragon lady(atleast for me) would be becomeing a lategame raidboss for teamfights(which was the case in S2/3).

And for most bruisers it's similar, they can do well early and snowballl on the back of that, buff if they hit mid/late on even terms, they feel completely usless.
